article:
'Mean time between failures (MTBF)' is the predicted elapsed time between
inherent failures of a system during operation. Jones, James V., Integrated
Logistics Support Handbook, page 4.2 MTBF can be calculated as the
arithmetic mean (average) time between failures of a system. The MTBF is
typically part of a model that assumes the failed system is immediately repaired
(mean time to repair, or MTTR), as a part of a renewal process. This is in
contrast to the mean time to failure (MTTF), which measures average time to
failures with the modeling assumption that the failed system is not repaired
(infinite repair rate).

The definition of MTBF depends on the definition of what is considered a system
failure. For complex, repairable systems, failures are considered to be those
out of design conditions which place the system out of service and into a state
for repair. Failures which occur that can be left or maintained in an
unrepaired condition, and do not place the system out of service, are not
considered failures under this definition. Colombo, A.G., and SÃ¡iz de
Bustamante, Amalio: Systems reliability assessment – Proceedings of the
Ispra Course held at the Escuela Tecnica Superior de Ingenieros Navales,
Madrid, Spain, September 19–23, 1988 in collaboration with Universidad
Politecnica de Madrid, 1988 In addition, units that are taken down for
routine scheduled maintenance or inventory control, are not considered within
the definition of failure.
